title: Aaron Rodgers and His Weird , Wild , Fabulous Life in and Outside the NFL
body_text:
- Aaron Rodgers is on the cusp of a high-profile trade to the New York Jets.
- The 39-year-old, who was overlooked as a college player, spent his pro career with the Green Bay Packers.
- He leads one of the most interesting and unconventional lifestyles off of the field.
Aaron Rodgers, one of the greatest passers in NFL history, is on the cusp of a high-profile move to the New York Jets.
Though Rodgers was overlooked as a college athlete, he joined the Green Bay Packers in 2005 and, up until this month, spent his entire pro career in Wisconsin, becoming one of the best-known names in sports.
But he's more than an athlete, as he's associated himself with blue-chip brands, been romantically linked to numerous famous women, and has an underrated sense of humor.
There's been highs, lows, championships, and controversies.
His 18 seasons with Green Bay was highlighted by a Super Bowl win over the Pittsburgh Steelers at the Cowboys Stadium in Texas, in February 2011.
Rodgers enjoyed one of the best seasons of his career in 2010, leading the Packers' offense to thorough beatings over the Philadelphia Eagles, the Atlanta Falcons, and the Chicago Bears in the lead-up to Super Bowl XLV.
In the big game, Rodgers completed 24 of his 39 passes for 304 yards and three touchdowns to lead his team to a 31-25 win and deservedly earn the Super Bowl MVP.
Perhaps, most importantly, that victory earned Rodgers a trip to Disney World. Look at that smile!
As has become custom, Rodgers could be heard bellowing: "I'm going to Disney World!" immediately after clinching the Super Bowl victory in Texas.
Few people have ever looked happier and more at home standing next to Mickey Mouse, surrounded by ticker tape.
Rodgers is renowned for his Hail Mary passes down the field.
Rodgers has made the Hail Mary a near-signature move and few highlights encapsulate his ability for coming in clutch than the time Richard Rodgers II caught his 61-yarder with literally 0:00 on the clock to beat the Detroit Lions 27-23.
The NFL dubbed the move: "The Miracle in Motown."
He earns approximately $68 million per season, from his salary and endorsements.
As a four-time NFL MVP, Rodgers has set numerous records including taking the fewest games (193) to reach 400 passing touchdowns.
It's little wonder that with so much on-field success, he's attracted endorsement deals with notable brands like State Farm, Adidas, Taylor Made, Bose, and Panini.
Those commercial contracts add approximately $11 million to his bank account every year.
He once requested to be paid partly in Bitcoin.
Rodgers signed a four-year, $134 million contract with the Green Bay Packers in 2018 and said in 2021 that he believes in Bitcoin. He even said that part of his $33.5 million per year salary would be paid in that cryptocurrency.
The mean average for Bitcoin was around $47,000 in 2021, according to Bloomberg. After a market crash in 2022, the crypto has gained momentum in 2023 and has a current price of $26,500 at the time of writing.
Source: Insider.
It seems to be as much about the fun as it is about the games for Rodgers, as he once skipped voluntary team workouts to gallivant around Hawaii with his girlfriend.
Rodgers passed on a voluntary off-season workout opportunity with the Packers in 2021 to instead travel to Hawaii with his then-fiancée, actress Shailene Woodley, and the actor Miles Teller and his wife, Keleigh.
Videos on their social media channels showed them hiking, frequenting swimming holes, and singing Taylor Swift songs.
I don't know about you, but that sounds to me like it beats a week in Wisconsin.
Source: Insider.
Rodgers also had fun on 'Jeopardy!' as the game show nerd appeared on the show both as a contestant and a host.
As a host, Rodgers wrote a load of sticky notes to display on the podium. Some included simple reminders like: "Stand up straight," and "slow down."
Others, as Insider reported at the time, were weirder: "Don't pick your butt/nose."
Source: Insider.
As COVID rampaged its way through the world and shuttered sports in 2020, Rodgers became a vocal critic of vaccination and NFL policy, attracting backlash.
Early in the pandemic, as sports executives attempted to integrate health and safety measures that would allow their leagues to return, Rodgers called out what he called "double standards" and openly wondered if it was all based on science.
During an appearance on "The Pat McAfee Show," Rodgers said that he wasn't for a reduction in protocol per se, but said some rules seemed to conflict with one another.
"You can go to practice and hit each other and be in close contact, but you have to have Plexiglass between you and the guy next to you in the locker room," he said in 2020.
A reporter asked Rodgers in 2021 if he had been vaccinated, and his answer — that he'd been "immunized" against COVID — caused an uproar many months later when it was revealed he had not been vaccinated.
In an interview on "The Joe Rogan Experience," Rodgers said his answer was designed to mislead the public and the media into thinking he'd had the vaccine when really he hadn't.
He said instead he had taken part in an "immunization process through a holistic doctor."
Later that year Rodgers said: "I'm in the crosshairs of the woke mob right now."
In 2022, he even said he believed people were tuning into certain matches — like the Packers-49ers game — to specifically root against him because of his vaccination status.
Sources: Insider, The Pat McAfee Show, CBS Sports, Insider.
Another side of his personality is that he's an avid reader, and though he gives regular book recommendations, there's always one story he returns to.
—Matt Schneidman (@mattschneidman) December 22, 2020
He's also a frequent golfer, even partnering up with Tour players like Bryson DeChambeau.
Rodgers and DeChambeau beat Phil Mickelson and Tom Brady with two holes to play in the 2021 installment of "The Match," to win $200,000 for charity.
Rodgers has a handicap of 3, meaning if there was a course with a par 72, he'd aim to shoot three over par at 75 — a very good score.
He played somewhat regularly at Green Bay CC in Wisconsin but it is unclear which course near the Metlife Stadium he'll call home when he moves to the East Coast.
Source: Golf.com.
Rodgers is romantically linked to Mallory Edens.
Mallory — the daughter of Wes Edens, a billionaire part-owner of the Milwaukee Bucks — is a model, writer, and activist.
The pair were even spotted at a Lakers-Bucks NBA game in December 2022.
Source: People and New York Post.
Rodgers was previously engaged to Shailene Woodley, an actress.
Woodley once quipped that, given the opportunity, she could not turn down a relationship with Rodgers because her dog would disown her, considering how good the quarterback would be at a game of "fetch."
They reportedly called off their relationship around February 2022, after keeping news of their engagement relatively quiet throughout the pandemic. Rodgers is said to have proposed back then with a ring that could be worth $500,000.
Prior to his relationship with Woodley, Rodgers was linked to fellow athlete Danica Patrick and actress Olivia Munn.
He has a somewhat complex relationship with his family.
Rodgers has a "complicated" relationship with his brother Jordan Rodgers, who won "The Bachelorette" show in 2017, family members said.
Aaron didn't even watch "The Bachelorette," for example. "I haven't seen the show to be honest with you, so it hasn't really affected me a whole lot," he told WISN.
Rodgers said he finds it "inappropriate to talk publicly about some family matters" but, regardless, wished him well "in the competition."
In 2018, Jordan accused Aaron of failing to check in on their parents when they were being evacuated during the California wildfires that year.
Then, in 2019, a report from Bleacher Report suggested that several former teammates described the superstar athlete as someone who was difficult to work with.
Sources: US Weekly, WISN, Insider, and Bleacher Report.
Rodgers likes to work on himself and is an advocate of yoga, meditation, and darkness retreats.
Rodgers once said on "The Pat McAfee Show" that meditation retreats and things like yoga have "stimulated my mind and helped me get in a better, better, better headspace."
He says it all helps him "have greater peace" in his life.
Rodgers even suggested in 2021 that meditation helped keep him from retiring that season. And, interestingly, NFL Hall-of-Famer Troy Aikman used Rodgers as an example to show meditation can make better leaders.
On darkness retreats, Rodgers said everyone could probably benefit from turning their phones off and disconnecting from things like technology and social media every once in a while.
However, he conceded that "some people don't want to do a few days and nights in darkness."
Sources: The Pat McAfee Show, Insider, and Insider.
Rodgers experimented with ayahuasca and found greater self-love as a result.
Rodgers has experimented with ayahuasca — a plant-based psychedelic — and said it bolstered his mental health.
It helped "see how to unconditionally love" himself, he said.
"Ayahuasca and psilocybin actually really helped" Rodgers overcome a prior fear of death, the quarterback added.
"I think when you've seen the other side it makes the idea of death more of a passage and less of an ending. More of kind of the next chapter of life," he said on "The Pat McAfee show."
Sources: The Pat McAfee Show, and Sports Illustrated,
Another form of wellness that Rodgers practices is called panchakarma.
Describing panchakarma as a "12-day cleanse," Rodgers said he adhered to a daily regiment that included a "specific diet" and "treatments."
He said: "You're not really doing anything else."
This, he said, allowed him to heal, re-center, and gain the spirituality he sought from the experience.
Part of that cleanse included a diet of drinking warm ghee, which is clarified butter, in the mornings, and using herbal laxatives in the evenings.
Other staples of the diet included rice, beans, vegetables, ginger, turmeric, and coriander.
Abstaining from things like cold food, sugar, dairy, drugs, alcohol, and caffeine is mandatory.
Sources: Sports Illustrated and Insider.
Rodgers has one of the most interesting, if unconventional, lifestyles in football, and will likely take that with him once his trade to the New York Jets is confirmed.
Rodgers told "The Pat McAfee Show" Wednesday that he intends to play for the New York Jets in 2023.
It remains unclear, though, whether the Jets can work out the trade with the Packers.
The two franchises are at the negotiating table but, as the New York Post noted Friday, they are at different ends in what they believe the trade is worth.
Sources: The Pat McAfee Show, New York Post,
